required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Visual Outcomes Following Descemet Stripping Automated Endothelial Keratoplasty
clinical_study.official_title: Visual Outcomes Following Descemet Stripping Automated Endothelial Keratoplasty for Corneal Endothelial Dysfunction

brief_summary.textblock: To assess objective and subjective visual outcomes achieved by patients with corneal endothelial dysfunction who have undergone surgical treatment with Descemet stripping automated endothelial keratoplasty (DSAEK).

detailed_description.textblock:
Since 2006, the technique by removing the Descemet membrane from the recipient cornea was renamed Descemet stripping automated endothelial keratoplasty (DSAEK). In recent years, DSAEK techniques have evolved, favoring increasingly thinner and finer grafts, known as ultrathin DSAEK (UT DSAEK), with the aim of obtaining better visual results.
Endothelial keratoplasty is now the most common surgical procedure used to treat endothelial dysfunction. The current study focused on assessing both objective and subjective visual quality outcomes following DSAEK.

primary_outcome.description: Scored with reference to the logarithm of the minimum angle of resolution (logMAR) and its variation in line gain.

study_pop.textblock: Patients with corneal endothelial dysfunction underwent DSAEK

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Clinical eligibility for DSAEK
- Informed written consent
- Successful completion of DSAEK procedure
- Postoperative follow-up at least 1 year
- Ability to respond to the questionnaire
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patients with clinical edematous cornea
- With significant stromal opacity
- With major disturbances of ocular surface
- Previous corneal surgery
